title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 07
author: Various
snippet: A young maniac mother,with a child at her breast, and dressed as a gipsy, endeavoured to crossthe Tweed between Norham and Ladykirk.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 20
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: After his marriage, Tom wentto sea for a few years, in command of the _Tweed_; but, on the death ofMr Keveley, he retired to Norham, where he took the cottage which theold gentleman had inhabited.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 20
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: About a fortnight after, on a fine forenoon, the village grocer atNorham was standing at his door, and gazing after a crowd which hadpassed; as he stood looking, a man dressed like a grazier came up, and,after the accustomed salutation of "How's a' wi' ye the day?" asked himwhat he was "glowrin" at.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 20
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: Tom, encouraged by these words, resolved, when the vessel should reachBerwick, to set out for Norham; which design he put in execution, a fewdays after, setting out from Berwick about six in the evening.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 20
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: Mr and Miss Keveley had retired to the village of Norham, beautifullysituated on the banks of the Tweed, where they continued for some timewith Tom's aunt, Mrs Burton.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 20
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: She informed him that they proposedsettling, for some time at least, in Norham.

title: The footpath and highway:
author: Moran, Benjamin
snippet: At Kelso is a fallen fane of the olden monks ; at Norham, a fine ruin of an ancient castle ', and at Berwick-on-Tweed, the remains of the walls which once inclosed the town.

title: My first visit to Europe:
author: Dickinson, Andrew
snippet: This famous cannon has seen hard times, having been at the siege of Norham, and a long time prisoner in the Tower of London,  but was finally restored to Scotland by the influence of Sir Walter Scott.

title: Gray Days and Gold ... New edition, revised, with illustrations
author: Winter, William
snippet: great trees, and looking directly east from this pointyour gaze falls upon all that is left of the stately Castleof Norham, formerly called Ublanford, — built by Flamberg, Bishop of Durham, in 1121, and restored by HughPudsey, another Prince of that See, in 1164.

title: Gray Days and Gold ... New edition, revised, with illustrations
author: Winter, William
snippet: The village of Norham lies a few miles west of Berwick, upon the south bank of the Tweed, — a group ofcottages clustered around a single long street.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: TheRegent, once more, with a fine army, made an attack upon Norham, a castle on the English frontier ; but when he had nearly gained this fortress,he suddenly, with his usual cowardice, left off tbeassault, on learning that Surrey was advancing toits relief.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: He speedily obtained possession ofthe Border fortresses of Norham, Wark, Etall,Ford, and others of less note, and collected a greatspinl.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: They were assembled in a large open plain, called Dpsettlington,opposite to the castle of Norham, but on the northern or Scottish side of the river.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: The gentlemen of the country entreated him toenter into terms with Sir Robert Kerr for sparingthis man's life ; but, having visited him in disguise, and learned his habits from his own mouth,Carey resolved that no conditions should save him,and caused him to be executed accordingly beforethe gates of the castle.2 In revenge of the deathof this man, Sir Robert Kerr very nearly surpriseda party of Carey's servants at Norham, who musthave been cut to pieces, had they not, by theirmaster's command, slept that night in the castle.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: A strong garrisonwas maintained in that city, ready at all times forservice; and, to have kept Berwick-upon-Tweed,was of itself a sufficient praise for a military man,and sums up, in a minstrel ballad, the character ofHarry Hotspur himself.6 When garrisons of regular troops were lodged, as was usually the case,in the royal castle of Norham, and Lord Grey'sbaronial castle of Wark, with smaller parties inthose of Etal, Ford, Cornhill, and Twizell, thecourse of the Tweed, where it divides the kingdoms, was well protected from invasion; and thenecessary siege of one or other of this chain of

title: Jane Seton: or, the Kings Advocate. A Scottish historical romance
author: Grant, James
snippet: A chain of royal castles watched the Enghshfrom the south, and the cannon of Berwick and Carlisle,Norham and Newcastle, frowned towards the Scottishmountains on the north.
